skill.name: using-agent-relay
skill.description: Use when coordinating multiple AI agents in real-time - provides inter-agent messaging via tmux wrapper (sub-5ms latency) or file-based team inbox for async workflows
skill.summary: Use when coordinating multiple AI agents in real-time - provides inter-agent messaging via tmux wrap...
skill.author: AgentWorkforce

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown documentation for inter-agent messaging patterns. No executable code, scripts, network calls, filesystem operations, or command execution capabilities. All 59 static scanner findings are false positives caused by misinterpretation of CLI examples and documentation text as security vulnerabilities.

content.user_title: Coordinate Multiple AI Agents in Real-Time
content.value_statement: Managing communication between multiple AI agents is complex and error-prone. This skill provides standardized patterns for real-time inter-agent messaging using tmux wrapper for sub-5ms latency or file-based async communication.
actual_capabilities: Real-time agent-to-agent messaging with fenced format syntax
Broadcast messages to all agents with ->relay:* pattern
Task delegation via spawn and release commands
File-based async team inbox for guaranteed delivery
limitations: Requires external agent-relay daemon to be running
Tmux mode limited to single host (no cross-host networking)
No guaranteed delivery in tmux mode (async team mode required)
External agent-relay CLI tool must be installed separately

use_cases.title: Parallel Code Development
use_cases.description: Coordinate multiple agents working on different features or modules of the same codebase simultaneously

use_cases.title: Multi-Agent Experiment Orchestration
use_cases.description: Run coordinated experiments where agents play different roles or test different approaches together

use_cases.title: Cross-Project Task Handoff
use_cases.description: Bridge multiple projects and hand off tasks between agents working on different codebases

prompt_templates.title: Delegate Task
prompt_templates.prompt:
->relay:AgentName <<<
TASK: [task description here]
Requirements:
- [requirement 1]
- [requirement 2]
Deadline: [if applicable]>>>

prompt_templates.title: Broadcast Status
prompt_templates.prompt:
->relay:* <<<
STATUS: [current status]
Progress: [% complete or description]
Next: [what comes next]>>>

prompt_templates.title: Request Code Review
prompt_templates.scenario: Ask another agent to review code
prompt_templates.prompt:
->relay:Reviewer [thread:review-name] <<<
REVIEW REQUEST: [component or file path]
Changes made:
- [change 1]
- [change 2]
Focus areas: [specific areas to review]>>>

prompt_templates.title: Spawn Worker Agent
prompt_templates.prompt:
->relay:spawn WorkerName claude <<<
[detailed task description with requirements]
Context:
- [relevant background]
- [important constraints]>>>

output_examples.input: Assign a login endpoint implementation task to a developer agent
output:
->relay:Developer <<<
TASK: Implement /api/login endpoint

Requirements:
- Accept email and password
- Return JWT token on success
- Return 401 on invalid credentials
- Add rate limiting (5 attempts per minute)

Files to modify:
- src/api/routes/auth.ts
- src/api/middleware/auth.ts

Return: Done when complete>>>

output_examples.input: Broadcast that the auth module is starting
output:
->relay:* <<<
STATUS: Starting auth module

Beginning implementation of authentication system.
Will need coordination with API team for token handling.
>>>

output_examples.input: Release a worker agent when their task is complete
output:
->relay:release Dev1

Worker agent Dev1 has completed the login endpoint. Releasing resources.

best_practices: Always use fenced format (<<<...>>>) for messages longer than 50 characters to avoid truncation
Use threads ([thread:name]) for ongoing conversations to keep related messages grouped
Broadcast STATUS updates to ->relay:* but send direct messages to specific agents for task assignments
anti_patterns: Using bash commands to send messages instead of outputting ->relay: patterns directly
Sending sensitive credentials or secrets via relay messages
Forgetting to read truncated messages before responding (use 'relay read <id>')

faq.question: Which AI tools are compatible with this skill?
faq.answer: This skill works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code. All three platforms support the ->relay: messaging syntax.

faq.question: What are the message size limits?
faq.answer: Fenced messages support up to 200 lines. Use relay read for truncated messages. For longer content, send a summary with a reference ID.

faq.question: How do I integrate this with my existing workflow?
faq.answer: Install the agent-relay CLI, start the daemon with 'relay -f', then output ->relay: patterns directly in your conversations.

faq.question: Is my message data stored securely?
faq.answer: Message data flows through the agent-relay daemon. Review your organization's data retention policies for relay logs and cached messages.

faq.question: Messages are not being delivered, what should I check?
faq.answer: Verify daemon is running with 'relay --status', ensure ->relay: pattern is at line start, and check for typos in recipient names.

faq.question: How does this compare to other multi-agent tools?
faq.answer: Agent-relay offers sub-5ms latency via tmux and guaranteed delivery via file-based mode. Most alternatives require additional infrastructure setup.
